page.title: 13 Conservation,Friar's Court
page.content: See page 12 In the planting of the shelter belts the farmer has made an interesting discovery. After initially planting his new trees in grass, with limited success, a chance observation made him experiment with planting his new trees and shrubs in young wheat. This proved most successful, possibly due to the aeration of the soil by the wheat roots, protection from the sun afforded by the mature wheat and the lack of matting by grass stems. With the addition of a plastic sack round the base of each sapling to repress weeds the resultant trees put on tremendous growth in their first year. The farmer is frustrated by a lack of information as to which trees are best to encourage helpful insects. A lake has been dug to encourage bird- life which will assist pest control.
